body.p: I have postponed to answer your letter of 27 January in the wanton hope to collect among your Danish friends an amount great enough to read you an order for a number of copies of your writings, that should be large sufficiently large to make impression on the newspapers in your own country.

My hope has been frustrated; I am myself a very lonely man without great connections, especially in the last years. Therefore my dear friend I can only beg you accept my sincere sympathy with your unfortunate condition. I have myself my considerable lot of difficulties. In these days I have got a little harbour for my old father and now I am going to marry
without fortune and closing all my expectations to the incertainuncertain fate of a book, which shall appear in the autumn. When this letter is in your hand, I most probably shall be a married man.
I shall as every time be glad to hear from you.

postscript.p: Have you not seen the name of Clemens Peter, seen newly in papers and periodicals—?
